title: Top #2: Spinning Top Toy for Inverted Soda Can

description.text:
Flip over a soda can, and spin the printed top. The top can spin for over three minutes with a good start.  
The concave shape of the bottom of a soda can provides an excellent base for a top.  
As long as the center of gravity of the top is below the tip on which the top spins, the top can spin for a very long time. My initial design of a top for an inverted soda can had the center of gravity above the top tip, and that top-heavy top could only spin for about 30 seconds with a good start.

author: PabloCagigal

description.text:
This is a top mount spool holder for 1kg spools for the m3d printer. It is a bit unstable but I believe it should hold - use it on your own risk, or as an inspiration for something better. The parts were all printed using the fast-thick wall setting - no filling.

Update: I've added an extension part to add more room to the top for high prints.

Contrary to other (similar solutions) here that I've found, this design is entirely printed and doesn't require other parts.

And yes, the printer is wrapped up in cellophane for isolation - reduces bending parts A LOT.

comments.text: Works really well for me. I have been using it for about a month and I am yet to have even the slightest of problems.

Tired of a rough start to your day?

Autobotsunite introduces Bubblebot - your happy alarm clock.

As part of our Mechatronics Course at DTU, we were assigned to design and create an innovative alarm clock.

Please check out this video and our blog for more information about our project, design challenges, and much more!

Also, check out the instructions to learn how to make your own.

/Autobotsunite

So you want to build your own alarm clock?

Here's what you will need:

  • Materials

  • Two 600x450x4 mm acrylic sheets
  • One 3 mm transparent acrylic sheet
  • A single 350x190x3 mm mdf sheet
  • A lot of soap bubble blowers
  • 8 Ø4x15 mm screws
  • A strong glue

Hardware

  • Arduino Mega 2560
  • Dc motor 5v (should run at about 15 RPM)
  • Blowing fan
  • 6 Buttons
  • LCD-display
  • Switch (On/off)
  • RTC
  • Ø10 x 115 Metal shaft
  • Power supply 12v 2a
  • Relay
  • Piezo element
  • Diodes
  • Breadboard
  • Resistors
  • A lot of wires

Software

  • Please use this Arduino code.
    For proper wiring, use the above circuit diagram.

Build it

  • To build the alarm clock, follow these steps.

  • Open the attached pdf-files and lasercut them. The living hinges should be cut on the mdf-sheets, and the rest of the components on the acrylic sheets. The basin should be cut on the thin transparent sheet, and the rest of the housing on the 4mm sheets. NOTE: The settings needed to cut the individual materials, depend on your lasercutter. You should always check the precice settings for the material BEFORE cutting, as the results greatly depend on these.

  • Open the boblearm.stl file and print TWO of these on your 3D-printer. We suggest using light-medium-infill and a decent layer thickness. The overall robustness of this component is however not a huge concer, so if you are in a hurry, you can choose a high layer thickness without compromising the result too much.

  • To put the housing together, start with gluing all the acrylic parts together (EXCEPT THE BACK AND TOP). To ensure the basin holds water, we suggest applying acetone on the inside. Once the glue is dry, you can apply the living hinges, by first gluing to one of the acrylic sides, wait for the glue to dry, then gently bent the hinge and glue it to the other acrylic part. Repeat this step for the remaining hinges. Check out the attached pictures for exact placement of components.

Now you're ready to install the electronics in the housing.

  • First install the motor, by screwing it to the interior wall. Now mount the shaft on the motor by screwing it on.
  • Add the arduinoboard, by also screwing it to the inteior wall
  • Add the breadboard to the interior wall (most breadboards have double-adhesive on the back.
  • Add the buttons and LCD to the side. We glued them on.
  • Add the switch and screw it on.
  • Screw the fan to the lasercut mount, and install in on the top side using glue.

Now you are ready to wire the whole thing. For this, please refer to the circuit diagram.

Finally you can upload the program to the arduino, and the alarm clock should be good to go!

We added some magnets to the backside of the cabinet, to ensure it stays on.

Happy prototyping!

/Autobotsunite

title: BATON!!! Prints in One Print - Already Assembled

description.text:
THIS BATON WILL PRINT IN ONE PRINT, WITH A SINGLE EXTRUDER, AND WITH NO SUPPORTS OR RAFT... MOST PRINTERS WILL BE ABLE TO PRINT IT PRETTY EASILY

Here is an Instructable teaching you how to set up your printer to print this baton... It's a very detailed and complicated deisgn with little room for error... So read the instructable before printing... It will tell you everything you need to know...

http://www.instructables.com/id/100-3D-Printed-Baton-LIGHTSABER-Prints-in-ONE-PRIN/

Here is a video of me explaining the baton...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DwO4HZPRfeI
Just download and print the baton and back stop... .3mm works best to save time... Try to print with at least 50% infill for strength.

A friend of mine has a TA01 chassis, but he lost his battery holder. I have a TA02 with the same part so I decided to model an 3D print the part.
I made it from red PLA. I have printed two in different orientation with different results. Needs some tweaking to make it perfect but It works fine. Drilled the hole for the clip after printing.

description.text:

P.S if you rotate duct in thingview you will see how it works ;)

author: carl10r

title: ep82gt Toyota Starlet Glowing TRD badge

description.text:
Hey Guys,

Some of the series 1 ep82 Toyota Starlets had a glowing rear GT badge, over the years, the harsh sun takes it toll on the vinyl which makes up the GT lettering, degrading it and it looks like ass, for the most part. I thought to myself, why not clean up the area, remodel the GT bit, print it out and slap it into the housing?!

I havent had a chance to print this yet, as i still dont have this particular garnish (my car has series 2, but ill be picking up an s1 piece shortly) and I am still working on refining the design, but all in all am pretty hopeful.

This is a variation of my original GT glowing badge, I've put the TRD logo in place of the GT logo.

Sketchup file is provided for those wishing to refine the design further!!

author: ChaosModder

description.text:
This is a small outboard motor kill switch key, however, it will fit any kill post which is about a centimeter in diameter and 5mm out.  So I suspect it will fit a lot of wave runners and jetski's as well.  Updated with a stronger back and slightly more forgiving angle for insertion.  
9/15/2015 update: A couple of people have asked what this will fit on. I made it for a Nissan outboard, but have used it on a Polaris Jetski, and with a bit of heat and some time with a pocketknife used one on a Yamaha waverunner.  What I guess I would ask, is since it clearly has been downloaded a lot of times, it would be wonderful if those people that use it for something, actually comment with the brand and model  Something like "Yamaha 2001 GP1200R" would be great...  Thanks!
Download, print.  connect to a lanyard and get wet!

comments.text:
Fits 1992 Yamaha 9.9hp 4-stroke outboard (T9.9ELH)
and 2006 Honda 9.9hp 4-stroke outboard (BF9.9D)

author: PinballGeorgio

description.text: Weird by XogtoX [created on 3DTin]

This is a funny case for the solderkit MK103

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iIxuvxY6HSF

This is another keychain.
It is holding an Australian $1 coin. The idea being that I will always have one dollar left - my last dollar.
I meant for the coin to be a slightly loose fit, but it is firm. I will make the ring a little larger.
BTW - Australian $1 is 2.5mm thick and 25mm diameter.

Ahhhh!
I put a chamfer on the inside space for the coin, and the edges of the chamfer make the space too small for the coin to be a loose fit.

Version two is thicker, but has enough space for the coin to move inside. It isn't loose, but it moves. I also added some cutouts to V2 to make the coin more visible, but I don't like how square it looks. :(

The coin has to be dropped in during printing.
Its hard to know when to drop it in.
There should be 0.5mm clearance around the coin, but it turned out a firm fit.
I put the coin in a little too soon and it got quite hot during the printing.

Version2
There is 0.5mm clearance around and above and below the coin.

title: Universal Spool Holder Makerbot Octave ToyBuilderLabs Filament Replicator 2, 2x, 1 V5

description.text:
I added in No Support Spool Holder which is now my recommended print. Generated support has come a long way and this now prints better that way. I also added a little reinforcement to keep the piece from breaking when in use. Still recommend 75%-100% infill V5 minor modifications to improve printing. Reinforced legs on the ToyBuilder and Makerbot holders so they are less likely to break if you push on them too hard.
V4 Added a ToybuilderLabs holder. Technically the Makerbot one will work but it's next to impossible to get it through the hollow center of the spool.
V3 Added a 10mm shorter Octave spool holder
Reinforced the walls of the Universal mount.
Highly recommend 100% infill for structural strength
Added the Inventor Project File
V2 extended the makerbot version so that it fits the larger spools.
Octave spool holder more flexible and rounded for better printing.
This is a spool holder that replaces the one that came with the 2X.
The "holder" is a univeral fit and can accept any type of Spool core.
Currently Makerbot and Octave are supported.

Print "Spool Holder" which attaches to the back of the 2x. I used double sided tape to secure mine to the machine but it will stay in without it. I Printed with .2mm 25% 2 shells and it was plenty rigid enough.
Print out one core for each of the filaments you have. I find it's a good way to test out a new reel or color. Then instead of having to remove each reel from the back of the machine, you simply lift up to remove and slide the new color into place.
Maker Spool is for the 60mm spools that makerbot sells and Octave is for the 10mm spools that are sold on amazon.
I've included support printing where it is needed to speed up print time and reduce waste. Makerbot slicing engine does some strange things sometimes because it's so thin. This is to be expected and shouldn't cause any problems.

author: Nogwa

title: PipBoy3000 Mk IV
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Beta Update (2015-07-25): I have the parts mostly joined together with the front sleeve (which has been rounded) and hollowed out for adding components (and maybe phones). It's split in two for minimizing wasted support within the screen void.

Original Description
Since (at the time of this writing) The Fallout 4 Collector's PipBoy edition is still a few months away from release, I thought I'd try my hand at making a printable pipboy to tide us Fallout fans over until the game arrives.

Rockin' and rollin' a bit lately. I'm starting to put in some of the finer details with a little help from user hippieman (Thanks).
I want to call this an alpha version of the model right now. The coarse details are blocked in, but most of the fine details (like buttons/knobs, vents, etc) are still pending.
This is still very much a WIP. I wouldn't even call it 50% at this point.

The rhino file is still the master blueprint of sorts, but the pipboy stl files have become quite printable if you want to give it a go. Assembly is still not quite as polished as I'd like it to ultimately be, but, hey alpha right?
I've included some sample stl files, but the meat of this is in the Rhino file (.3dm)

Beta Update (2015-07-25): Turn on support and orient the body parts with the ring openings down against your build platform. The clasp you'll have to play with, but I haven't found a way to design it with a flat side just yet, so orient it however you can minimize support without compromising the print.

I'll eventually overhaul the naming slightly since it's a little confusing at the moment.

Easiest way to explain which files you need is grab every stl with the version level you want (currently it's just 'alpha', when things start to get more polished I'll move to 'beta').

Then for each part name with multiple numbers (alpha2.back_tube.stl, alpha3.back_tube.stl), just keep the highest numbered file and delete the lower one(s).

Its's up to you to arrange them for printing in your slicing software. Some parts currently have nasty overhangs and will either need support added and or have their print orientations played with to minimize print defects and wasted support material (YMMV).

The screen parts mostly line up well together, but that assembly doesn't key into the arm tube/sleeve (you'll see) so you have to play with the orientation when ultimately gluing the current version together.

comments.text: That's pretty awesome for just a couple of hours work. I'm shooting for being in-game accurate, but its hard with the limited data we've been given. I have to fill in gaps with the PipBoy Edition, which I think deviates from the game in some places because of manufacturing compromises (and maybe because they have to shoehorn a phone into it).
comments.author: Raveyote

comments.text: Thanks, You grabbed some pretty good ones, got a few angles I had to only guesstimate from. I might poke around your file and help contribute, since yours has the general shape buy lacks the finer little details, though I'm sure that's all coming in time. What have you been printing it in out of curiosity, since it might be easier to solvent weld certain parts together if you have certain parts separate. Also, do your knobs and buttons move, or are they static?
comments.author: juancgarcia

comments.text: I've been using PLA, so acetone has no effect. "For plastic" 2-part epoxy has worked well so far with some of my other PLA prints.  I've just got the eject button, mode selector knob and the scroll wheel. They aren't fixed to the rest of the model, but don't have any proper mount points yet either. For now it just makes it easier to paint them independent of the body, but will have to be glued down unless you manually come up with a way to mount them for turning/pressing.
comments.author: Raveyote

comments.text: Well for the knobs, perhaps design them around a rotary encoder/potentiometer knob bracket, since that would allow for future functionality if people choose to try to integrate that into future versions. As for the selector switch might be smart to design it around like a cherry or boalian with that they typically use for arcade machine buttons, good for like 100,000 cycles. The later use 2 screw mounting holes which vary by manufacturer but wouldn't be hard to design peg holes to hold them and by function the switch above, and as for the knobs, you'd just leave small circular hole for mounting the barrel of the pot/encoder, and then the knob fits snugly on the barrel (Maybe with locktite) and the barrel is mounted to the plane by means of a locknut and a washer. But that's how I'd do it. Alternatively you could just glue it down or 3D print some clever connector.
comments.author: juancgarcia

comments.text: The current plan I'm shooting for is to just hollow out the model enough for people to customize the knob/button mounting themselves or alternatively glue everything static as a dumb prop or display piece. If a pattern emerges of people using similar pots or buttons I'll take the feedback to design in screw holes or other convenience brackets to support that. I just don't want to do a bunch of work up front standardizing for an arbitrary set of hardware that might end up being hard to find or that the community doesn't like.

description.text: This is a simple caster designed for a robot I'm making, hopeful one of these days it will be finished. The caster uses a 16mm marble for the ball. It may be possible to print a ball for it, but I have not yet tried it. A few things to note are: Most marbles are glass, so there is a chance of them breaking and you may need to increase the "ballDiameter" variable, in the scad file, by 0.5mm if you are using a different marble size so it can rotate freely.

comments.text: I do a lot of woodworking. I can set u a bed of these to use as support, say on a table saw extension, or support for any of my shop tools. The Ball Bearing is a better idea.

title: LulzBot Taz 4 power supply PC cooling fan adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WARNING: Power supplies contain high voltage. Monkeying around in them can be fatal. Always unplug before touching anything, and familiarize yourself with high voltage safety. If you are not comfortable doing this sort of work, please don't do it.

I love my LulzBot Taz 4, but recently, the power supply started squealing like a pig, and generally making horrible noises, suggesting that the cooling fan was dying a slow and painful death. I knew I had to fix it right away.

A thorough cleaning of the stock cooling fan didn't fix the problem, so it became apparent I would need to replace it. I scrounged around for a suitable fan, and found this Cooler Master CM12V, which is a pretty standard CPU cooling fan for a desktop PC. The CM12V had a 3-wire plug, while the original Taz fan only had 2 wires. I chopped both cables and spliced the wires together (red to red, black to black), disregarding the extra (yellow) wire on the CM12V. I twisted the wires together and soldered them, finally wrapping them in electrical tape to prevent shorts.

At first, I fashioned a primitive cardboard fan mount, and held it in place with electrical tape. This worked long enough to print the ABS version, which I immediately installed in its place.

So far, it seems to be working fine. I use my Taz pretty heavily, and the factory fan lasted about one year. If I have to change the fan every year, I want it to be accessible, standardized, and easily swapped. This system is much better (IMHO) than the stock fan, which I actually broke trying to remove, because it refused to come off of the top cover. The power supply also seems to breathe easier in this open configuration, meaning it outputs more heat through natural convection and doesn't need to turn on the cooling fan nearly as much.

Don't leave yours open like this if you have small children or pets that like to climb around on things -- they could be electrocuted. Otherwise, I think this is a great solution to the problem of having an unreliable and unserviceable cooling fan.

Printed in black ABS. Assembled with #4-40x1" brass machine screws, nuts, and washers.

Make sure to bolt those screws on hard enough that they don't fall into the power supply and short something out.

comments.text: It's a shame that the TAZ 4 shipped with a total piece of shit Chinese power supply.  The bearings in the fan on mine started to seize up after only a few months, so I emailed LulzBot and they sent a replacement.  In the meantime, I replaced the fan with a Cooler Master I had in a junk bin.  At some point, I plan to replace the entire supply with an industrial grade one.  The construction and assembly of the PCB in the stock supply is downright atrocious.  I don't even leave mine plugged in when my printer is switched off, because I don't trust it to not spontaneously catch fire.  Anyway, nice work, and thanks for sharing this!
comments.author: bfesser

comments.text: Yeah, my luck with the Taz 4 was slightly better than yours (my power supply lasted a whole year, lol!), but I agree that it must have been the cooling fan bearings that burned out.  No problems since I replaced the cooling fan.  And exposed HV is my favorite anti-theft device.  ;-)
comments.author: bfesser

comments.text: What size is the fan that you mounted?
comments.author: WIRGaming

comments.text: I think it may have been 70mm -- I can't remember for sure.  I know they come in 70, 80, and 90mm dimensions.  I think the 70s are more rare.  A clever person could mod the design files to suit their particular needs.
comments.author: WIRGaming

comments.text: Well im not too clever in 3D Design. Thanks ill try to find a 70mm 12v fan for that psu now because Im having the same problem

remixed_from.author: summetj
remixed_from.title: Parametric Horizontal Spool Roller (for rostock-mini, Octave, MakerGear, othes)

description.text:
This is a handle that mounts via an M8 socket head cap screw (SHCS) or hex bolt/nut. I use it on the same that normally holds my horizontal spool roller on the top of my rostock-mini when it's in use.  
The handle is parametric so you can make it a different size by editing the OpenSCAD file. The two STL files provided will work with either a round SHCS or with a hex head bolt or a hex nut.

Print. Attach to whatever you want to carry/open using an M8 bolt, either a hex bolt or a SHCS depending upon what version you printed. If you are using a bolt or SHCS, it should be 30mm or less to fit inside the handle. If you need a longer bolt, you can come in from the back and use a hex nut inside the handle.

comments.text: how is the mini working?, have you made any modification to the original mini design?, im tempted to build one!
comments.author: nic0laz

comments.text: The printer is working well. It is mostly stock for the motion platform. You can see my modifications (look at all of my "Things" on thingiverse). The biggest change is that I made my own spring loaded print bed, so the bed is adjustable instead of the endstops. I also made the top acrylic piece solid, so that I can mount my spool roller (and handle) on the top (along with the extruder cold end) The original design doesn't specify a working extruder, so I made my own out of a Greg's Wade extruder with a hacked together bowden tube adapter.

description.text:
Custom cookier designed using CookieCaster: http://www.cookiecaster.com

Dimensions:
Longest Length: ~3.0 inches (7.6 cm)
Height: 0.4 inches (1.0 cm)
Thickness: 0.06 inches (1.5 mm)

CookieCaster cookie cutters are easily printed on your MakerBot using the standard settings - we recommend using PLA to print and then saran wrap for cutting to make cleanup easy and to prevent any loose plastic from getting in your cookies

370 motor
10mm max propeller

This is very much a work in progress. This is something that I want to form the back bone of the Anthromod Hand v2.0 and Hollies prosthetic hand development. You need to open the f3d file with fusion 360. You can also download here http://a360.co/1BMrjEf

It is designed in Fusion 360. It describes a set of 4 blocky fingers that can be adjusted in many ways via changing the parameters.

My aim is that the final hand will be very flexible and allow me to change almost everything about it, from number of fingers to length of finger, to joint type etc etc.
This flexibility will be very useful when I need to insert joints into scanned hands like I plan to in the next round of Hollies hand.

A reminder that I'll be able to keep putting time into projects like this if you donate to http://www.gofundme.com/prosthetic-hand

The stl is just to keep thingiverse happy. I don't recommend printing it!

C60 based structure comprised of Pentagon and Hexagon plates connected to center core by coil springs. I first designed this in 2001. Feel free to download and build I made one error on this design, the lack of filleting on the "coil to plate core junction" and "plate junctions" will reduce its resistance to fracture from cyclic deformations. However in Nylon it works fine.
  • Always be generous with fillets for surfaces undergoing cyclic tensile stress - especially at the acute apex of the junction.
  • with springs always over model position as typically they will creep deform to a stable state after initial cycling
    • Note it will Bounce just like a rubber ball
  • send me photos - enjoy ! Pat
Works best on in Nylon an SLS System or any other process where the support structures do not exist or wash / dissolve away.

Our kids love our Thermos Foogo bottles. Unfortunately, the base of the bottles is just hot-glued on, and they tend to fall off after some dishwasher cycles. The original plastic bases are too loose to stay attached without the glue bond, and I'm not sure how to re-glue them. So here is a printable replacement that has a snug enough snap-on fit that it will stay put without glue.

The part is designed to be printed using Taulman PCTPE. It needs to use a somewhat flexible material, or else it will be impossible to snap onto the stainless steel bottle.

Remove any remaining glue from the bottom of the stainless steel bottle. It will take 80 pounds or so of pressure to snap the part onto the bottom of the bottle.

I friend brought me a handful of broken pieces that were part of his weight machine. He described them as cable brackets that kept the cable on the pulleys of the machine while the weights moved. I designed and printed them without seeing the system, he told me the next day they were a perfect fit and he was able to safely use his weight machine again. I do not have the name or model of the machine these were designed for, I'll just put them here in case someone is looking.
Printed at 50% fill for added strength.

description.text: Have a pocket knife that you really wish had a clip? I did, so I made this 3D printable mold. I used vacuum resin infusion which I had access to in my research lab to lay carbon onto the mold and infuse it. After it cured and after some shaping with a dremel, I had a nice new knife clip.

Step 1, Print the mold. This can be done with any material, at whatever settings you're used to. A high level of infill is not essential, although less than 10% may result in the mold caving in under pressure.

Step 2, Treat the mold. I used an acetone vapor bath (having printed the mold out of ABS) to smoothen the surface. I then added several coats of Freekote release agent, although many people use car wax as well. Lastly, I laid down a layer of peel-ply, which is a special type of thin permeable fabric. Not all of these may be completely necessary; the purpose of all of this is to ensure that the epoxy does not stick to the mold, as a part glued to the mold is useless. Do what you think is necessary, and experiment first.

Step 3, Lay fibers into the mold. I used 3 layers of woven carbon fiber, at 0/90, ±45, 0/90 orientations, with fiber weight at 300g/m^2. I cut the fiber so it would overlap the edges of the mold, ensuring I would have the mold completely covered, and enough area to cut my clip out of.

Step 4, Infuse with resin. I did this using the vacuum resin infusion method. This is done as follows: set the mold (mold, peel-ply, fiber) on top of a glass plate. on top of the fibers, add an additional layer of peel-ply, and a larger layer of vacuum bagging. Insert a disposable host on either end, and use tacky tape to seal all around the hoses and vacuum bagging to the plate. run one hose to a vacuum pump, turn it on, and clamp off to seal the other hose. Check for leaks. When satisfied, dip the end of the sealed off hose in a cup of epoxy, and unclamp the hose. Resin will be sucked through the fibers to the other hose. If you notice bubbles appearing, it is likely because you have a small leak that you did not know about, so stand by ready to attack leaks with tacky tape, as these bubbles will result in a part with cavities between fibers, which will make it much weaker. When the resin reaches the other end, clamp off the resin supply end hose again. Allow resin to cure before removing the vacuum. (I have a resin trap between my vacuum pump and my part, with a pressure guage and a valve between the trap and the pump. This allows me to turn on the vacuum to vacate the trap, close the valve, and turn off the pump. This allows me to keep the vacuum even with the pump off, as well as to check for leaks easier, as I both don't need the pump running so leaks are easier to hear, and because I can watch the pressure gauge and observe any increases in pressure, indicative of small leaks that I may not be able to hear).

Alternate Steps 3 and 4: Alternatively, either pre-preg could be used (pre-impregnated fibers), or resin could be brushed on. The challenge will be getting the fibers to conform to the curves of the mold. One method of doing this is rather than using atmospheric pressure and a vacuum, use a balloon pressing the fibers into the mold. This would be similar to the bladder molding process.

Step 5, Remove part from mold. If you think you may want to make more, be careful with the mold, so as to not destroy it.

Step 6, Trim edges to the desired shape. I used a dremel tool for this, and I was able to get 2 knife clips out of one mold/infusion. Also drill the required holes.

Step 7, Attach clip to knife. I'll let you figure that part out, although watch out for rotation. My knife only has one hole in the tail of it, which means with one small bolt through that hole and attached to my clip, the clip can rotate about the axis of the bolt. A drop of super glue under the clip solves this, although this means I would be unable to remove the clip without damaging it if i wanted to in the future (you can dissolve the super glue with acetone, but that will also affect the resin in the fibers). If you have 2 holes, make use of both of them.

And you're done! Cheers!

Let me know if you have any questions on the process. My background is in composites processing and I had all the resources of a composites laboratory to work with, so the infusion step only took me about 15 minutes to set up, although most people do not have such resources. Let me know and I will be happy to help if you want to either learn more about the processes I mentioned, or try to figure out another way to do it given the resources you have.

title: Cellphone Stand for camera use, like old days. Customizable.

description.text:
If you want to use your cellphone's camera with the delay timer, like the old days, but just can't get it properly set up this is the print for you.

It can be easliy modified to fit any special needs your phone needs.

Really easy.

Scale and print "Pedestal Cam" to fit your cellphone width (I have a Nexus 5). You print it and glew it to "Pedestal Cabezal".

"Pedestal Base" and "Pedestal Cabezal" are originally ment for a long, 4mm screw but you can scale it as you see fit. The screw fits snuggly but you can screw it in with no problem.

"Llave 1" is ment to fit the nut so you can easily losen the head, point the camera, and then tighten it again.

Cheers!

author: ellasaro

title: Customizable Marble Machine - Self locking components

description.text:
I loved the marble machine that Jazzmyn created. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:892619 It's awesome. I thought I'd contribute by making some clips and rings that hold the track in place without the use of zip ties. I created new clips and the ring so that the track is held in place with pressure from the clip and kept from rotating by adding notches to the clips and ring. The clips should work with the smooth rings if you already have them printed, they just may not hold the position as well.

The clips may need a quick slice along the middle to separate any strings that form along the small gap.

I hope everyone finds these useful

This is the final version of my printable washer. No need to remove all the nuts and parts to add a fender washer. Plus fender washers can be hard to find. It has an open face so you can insert it directly on the threaded rod. Its bed facing side is removed to the minimum needed to allow the Y-bed to travel all the way up to bearing. More print space!
Download the stl file. Run through your favorite skinning program (Skeinforge, Repsnapper, etc.) load the gcode into a reprap host and print. Use.

description.text:
Meine Katze liebt kleine Köstlichkeiten. Damit sie ihr aber nicht nur auf die Hüften schlagen, soll sie sich auch ein wenig anstrengen, um sie zu bekommen.

Hier ist mein erster Versuch dazu. Die Katze muss die Knuspertaschen mit ihrer Pfote aus dem Becher herausholen. Obwohl sie sichtlich genervt davon ist, dass der Genuss ihrer Leckerlis nun erschwert ist hat sie eine Beschäftigung und verbringt eine gewisse Zeit damit, nach ihnen zu angeln.

Durch den großen Fuß ist es für die Katze sehr schwer, den Becher umzuwerfen.

My cat loves culinary delights. To prevent that she only becomes fat, she now has to struggle a little bit.

This is my firt try. The cat has to get her treats out of this cup with her paw. Though she is visibly annoyed that access to her delights is hindered now she uses pretty much time to get them out.

Due to the big base of the cup, it's pretty hard for the cat to knock it over.

title: Venetian gondola - E3D V6 chiller for 3DRag K8200

description.text:
Was not much satisfied both from the E3D V6 interface to 3Drag and the cooling setup for the metal Hotend . . .
Hence this new design.
It uses 2 x 40 mm fans to both for a great airflow and redundancy (2 is better than one!).
The inlet fan has an aerodynamic insert to avoid turbolence and preserve dynamic pressure.
Both the Fans are oriented to avoid creating cold draughts on the printed piece and it is possible to duct them for encased installation.
The interface to the 3Drag had been based on the work of Owl1981 "e3d v6 to 3Drag/K8200 adaptor" which had been made more robust and modified to be interfaced with the chilling tunnel!
To free from any weight the Extruder you should print also the Base Plate which had been based on the work by Boris Landoni "
Print flex filaments with 3Drag/K8200" with minor changes (most important one is having the nuts merged into the base also for the extruder to avoid the connection getting loose).
This way you'll be able to start printing with flexible filaments right away!
The fans must always be on until the hotend has been completely cooled down to avoid deformations.

Enjoy!

title: Axe Z pour smartrapCore (alternative Z axis)

description.text:
Un nouvel axe Z pour la smartcore, sans porte à faux

possibilité d'utiliser un hot bed MK2 . Verre de 22cm de coté.

This new Z axis for the smartcore should improve the bed stability,
It's compatible with a MK2 bed.

The glass plate is assumed to be the one provided with the Smartfriendz kit ( 22cm square )

This design shoult work with any box based Core XY ! Let me know by posting in "I made one" !

02/12/2015
légère modification de la poulie
Light tweeking of the bearing spool

30/11/2015
MAJ importante : réalignement complet suite au passage à des poulies sur les pièces UP
Réimprimez TOUT, ou rien ! ( sauf accessoires)
Ajout des pièces "optional bearing" pour monter un roulement sur un des trous de fixation du nema 17 afin d'améliorer l'enroulement autour de la poulie moteur.
(Tous les Sliders ont été mis a jour)
Les poulies ( bearing spool) sont à imprimer en scalant un peut (101~102%), faites des tests avant de lancer un batch complet !

Important Update: Complet realignment of the geometry after adding spools on the Up bearings. Re-print the whole set or nothing ! (exept accessories)
Added "optional bearing" parts , which you may fix to one of the NEMA's fixation hole to maximize the belt grip around the motor spool .(see picture)
(every sliders are up to date)
Spools may need some scale up (101~102%). Test print before launching the full set !!!

30/10/2015
julien nous a fait une version "poulies" des pièces top. http://talk.smartfri.odns.fr/index.php?topic=668.0
Plus de déraillement de la courroie ;)

Thx to julien (http://talk.smartfri.odns.fr/index.php?topic=668.0) , tops part now works with spools, wich makes the system more reliable !

-10/08/2015
UP L&R modifié : trous de fiaxation
Afin de pouvoir garantir l'alignement des poulies, on peut désormais régler l'inclinaison de ces pièces. utiliser une rondelle pour le plus gros trou.

update on UP L&R parts : fixation holes.
Some misalignment conducted in the belt to slide sideways of the bb. With this update it's now possible to finetune the alignment.,
Use a washer with the bigger hole.

STEP and Solidworks files here :

https://www.dropbox.com/sh/1nty6k0aptx1sfa/AAAN01kmu05vEyh1QdxaoK2_a?dl=0

Part list :

4 more std bearings (5 in all)
4 M8 20 screw
1 d8 20 mm Stub ( blb axis near the motor)
2x d8 * 245 mm Stub
4 LM08 bearings
1.65m Gt2 belt

optional bearing :
1x bearing
1x M3*20 screw

-Placez les pièces up et corner a 136mm du fond de la boite.
Up and Corner parts should be at 136mm from the botom of the box.

Imprimez 3 poulies (pour les roulements supérieurs et le roulement optionnel)
Print 3 spools ( upper bearings ans optional one)

There is a picture with some dimentions for you to drill your wood bed at the right places.

Please note that the bruno bellamy's landing gear is an option, and that you will find it here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:968461
